Impact of the percentage of compromised clients.
Table¬†1 shows the impact of the percentage of compromised clients under LIE attack on CIFAR-10 with the non-IID degree q=0.5ùëû0.5q=0.5. We observe that as the percentage of attackers increases, the accuracy of all the defenses decreases. However, the degree of decreased accuracy varies from different defenses. Krum performs the worst. When there are 10%percent1010\% attackers, its accuracy is only 43.13%percent43.1343.13\%, which is 32.38%percent32.3832.38\% lower than the Baseline. When attackers account for 20%percent2020\% or more, Krum fails to converge (with the accuracy of 10%percent1010\%). FABA, Median, and LFR perform better than Krum, the accuracy gap between them and the Baseline is no more than 8%percent88\% in the case of 10%percent1010\% attackers. However, the gap widens significantly as the number of attackers increases to 30%percent3030\%. When attackers account for more than 30%percent3030\%, the three defenses fail to converge. FLTrust outperforms the above four defenses. When there are no more than 20%percent2020\% attackers, FLTrust is not heavily affected, with the accuracy of about 8%percent88\% lower than the Baseline. We also notice that FLTrust possesses the accuracy of 46.42%percent46.4246.42\% even in the case of 48%percent4848\% attackers, which is drastically higher (i.e., 36.42%percent36.4236.42\%) than that of the above four defenses. However, it is about 30%percent3030\% lower than that of the Baseline, which means that FLTrust fails to offer a satisfactory global model in high-percentage attackers scenarios. In contrast, the proposed FPD achieves the best performance all the time. More importantly, it is highly stable. Specifically, its accuracy drops from 74.81%percent74.8174.81\% to 71.61%percent71.6171.61\% as the fraction of attackers increases from 10%percent1010\% to 48%percent4848\%.

Impact of the non-IID degree.
Table¬†2 shows the impact of the non-IID degree under LIE attack on CIFAR-10 with 30%percent3030\% compromised clients. We observe that as the non-IID degree qùëûq varies from 0.1 (i.e., the IID case) to 0.95 (i.e., the extremely non-IID case), all the schemes (including Baseline) achieve a lower and lower accuracy gradually. However, the accuracy of FPD is invariably comparable with that of Baseline (with the accuracy gap of 0.30%‚àº2.08%similar-topercent0.30percent2.080.30\%\sim 2.08\%). FLTrust and LFR perform well when q=0.1ùëû0.1q=0.1 and q=0.3ùëû0.3q=0.3. However, when q‚â•0.5ùëû0.5q\geq 0.5, their accuracy drops dramatically, which indicates that FLTrust and LFR do not apply to non-IID scenario. Krum, FABA, and Median cannot obtain a high-quality global model even in IID setting (i.e., q=0.1ùëû0.1q=0.1) due to the remarkable attack effect of LIE attack.

Ablation study on the absence of modules.

Without module BùêµB, the global model accuracy under LIE attack drops 4.85%percent4.854.85\%, which means that module BùêµB is effective to defend against colluding attacks. Without module Cùê∂C, the combination cannot achieve a desirable global model accuracy under non-colluding attacks (i.e., LF and SF attacks), demonstrating the necessity of module Cùê∂C.

Previous experiments have demonstrated that FPD exhibits superior defense performance against individual colluding attacks or non-colluding attacks. As a result, one may naturely wonder whether FPD can withstand

, a group of attackers deploy colluding attacks while the remaining deploy non-colluding attacks. To this end, we conduct MA (half of attackers deploy LIE and the other half deploy LF) and compare it with LIE and LF, the results are shown in Tab.¬†

. Surprisingly, MA is not stronger than LIE, and sometimes even weaker than LF. Specifically, our FPD performs consistently well under the three attacks with the highest accuracy, demonstrating its superiority in eliminating malicious updates. For FLTrust and LFR, MA is somewhat effective, but its impact is intermediate between that of pure LIE and LF. This is because both defenses are effective in defending against LF, but are weak in identifying LIE attackers. As for Krum, FABA, and Median, MA has the slightest effect on accuracy, we speculate that MA makes malicious updates more dispersed, thus making it easier for these similarity-based defenses to identify benign updates.
